title: Boris Johnson Makes Last-Ditch Brexit Bid to EU
text:
MANCHESTER, England—British Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Wednesday announced a revised Brexit proposal, warning the European Union that he remains prepared to take the U.K. out of the bloc at the end of October without a deal.

In a speech at the Conservative Party’s annual conference that was light on detail, Mr. Johnson urged EU officials to help find an agreement over the terms of Britain’s split with the bloc, more than three years after Britain voted to leave the EU.

“Today in Brussels we are tabling what I believe are constructive and reasonable proposals which provide a compromise for both sides,” Mr. Johnson said.

But his approach toward negotiating a deal before the end of the month risks further entrenching division between the two sides, with time running short before a crunch summit in Brussels that starts on Oct. 17.

The U.K. government is set to disclose the details of its proposals in a letter later Wednesday, officials said. The EU negotiating team will meet with diplomats from the remaining 27 countries to discuss the proposal on Wednesday evening, European officials said.

Mr. Johnson sought to address a dilemma at the center of a Brexit riddle that has paralyzed Parliament and claimed the premiership of one prime minister: the land border between Northern Ireland, which is in the U.K., and Ireland, a separate EU member state.

Mr. Johnson indicated that under the proposal, Northern Ireland would withdraw along with the rest of the U.K. from the EU’s customs union, while remaining inside the bloc’s regulatory orbit for agriculture and manufactured goods. He said customs checks wouldn’t be necessary “at or near the border,” implying that the necessary checks would be carried out using behind-the-border technology.

“If we fail to get an agreement because of what is essentially a technical discussion of the exact nature of future customs checks—when that technology is improving the whole time—then let us be in no doubt that the alternative is no deal,” he said.

EU officials have pointed out in the past that such technical solutions aren’t in operation at any land border in the world, and doubt that any could be ready in the next couple of years.

British lawmakers have already thrice rejected a Brexit deal that was negotiated last year, leading to two delays to the original departure date of March 29. Since his arrival at Downing Street this summer, Mr. Johnson has repeatedly vowed to get the U.K. out of the EU by the end of October.

Mr. Johnson’s approach has fanned concerns among some British lawmakers and EU officials over whether he is serious about getting a divorce deal or whether he wants the U.K. to leave the bloc without an agreement to smooth its exit.

Britain’s Parliament has passed a law that states if a deal with the EU isn’t agreed by Oct. 19, the government must request a further three-month extension to negotiations. It would be up to the EU’s other 27 members whether to accept such an extension.

Unless Mr. Johnson can get a deal with the EU, it looks increasingly likely that an extension will have to be requested, analysts say.

Some in Britain are sounding alarms on the potential consequences of the U.K. crashing out of the EU without a deal. WSJ’s Saabira Chaudhuri takes a look at what a no-deal Brexit could look like for businesses, the economy and consumers.

Mr. Johnson, whose party has a minority in Parliament, wants a general election to clear out pro-EU lawmakers who are currently blocking his plans. The opposition parties have blocked such a vote until a no-deal Brexit on Oct. 31 is off the table.

In the deal negotiated by Mr. Johnson’s predecessor, Theresa May, an arrangement, known as the Irish backstop, was agreed on to prevent the need for customs posts and related physical infrastructure along the 310-mile frontier separating Northern Ireland from the Republic of Ireland.

But the backstop was toxic to hard-line pro-Brexit lawmakers in the ruling Conservative Party and—critically—to Mrs. May’s allies in Northern Ireland’s Democratic Unionist Party, whose support she relied upon to govern.

The backstop called for the U.K. to remain within the EU’s common customs area until a new free-trade accord could be agreed between London and Brussels. It also called for Northern Ireland to remain wedded to EU regulations in sectors such as agriculture and manufactured goods, to eliminate the need for regulatory checks on goods and animals crossing the border.

Pro-Brexit lawmakers said that agreeing to such provisions would leave the U.K. too closely tied to the EU after Brexit, and unable to escape the arrangement. Mrs. May’s Northern Irish allies said the backstop risked weakening Northern Ireland’s links to the rest of the U.K.

Excising the backstop from the withdrawal package and replacing it with new arrangements has became Mr. Johnson’s central negotiating goal. In a letter to European Council President Donald Tusk not long after taking office, Mr. Johnson described the backstop as antidemocratic and inconsistent with the sovereignty of the U.K.

Write to Max Colchester at max.colchester@wsj.com and Jason Douglas at jason.douglas@wsj.com
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced a revised Brexit proposal, warning the European Union that he remains prepared to take the U.K. out of the bloc at the end of October without a deal.
